titleStmt.title: The lavvyer of Lincolnes-Inne reformed: or, An apology for the army. Occasioned by IX queries, upon the printed charge of the army, against the XI members, and the papers thereto annexed; submitted to the publique consideration of all lovers of justice, truth, parliaments, army, and their native countrey. / By the author of The case of the kingdome, &c.

titleStmt.title: The lavvyer of Lincolnes-Inne reformed: or, An apology for the army. Occasioned by IX queries, upon the printed charge of the army, against the XI members, and the papers thereto annexed; submitted to the publique consideration of all lovers of justice, truth, parliaments, army, and their native countrey. / By the author of The case of the kingdome, &c.

notesStmt.note: The author of The case of the kingdome, &c. = Marchamont Nedham.
A reply to: Prynne, William. IX queries upon the printed charge of the army against the XI. members and the papers thereto annexed (Wing P4023).
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE LAVVYER OF LINCOLNES-INNE REFORMED: OR, An Apology for the Army.

Occa≈øioned by IX Queries, upon the Printed Charge of the Army, again≈øt the XI Members, and the Papers thereto annexe ‚Ä¢ ; ≈øubmitted to the publique con≈øideration of all Lovers of Ju≈øtice, Truth, Parliaments, Army, and their native Countrey.
By the Author of The Ca≈øe of the Kingdome, &c.

q.p: They only con≈øult to ca≈øt him down from his excellency, they delight in lies.

div.p: Printed in the Yeare, 1647.

div.head: The Lawyer of LINCOLNES-INNE Reformed.
div.p: SInce this Learned Gentlemans u≈øuall way of Queries, argue rather a di≈øea≈øe of ill concoction in the Brain, than any rea≈øonable Conclu≈øion of what He undertakes, and is but a piece of Leiger-du-maine to amu≈øe mens Under≈øtandings, by feeding the Phanta≈øie with ≈øuch Feares and Jealou≈øies, as the weaker ≈øort of men (fruitfull enough in the≈øe times) create unto Them≈øelves out of what they read, rather than any Satisfaction to the more ≈øolid part of the world: Give leave then to wonder, how He or any man dare owne ≈øo much Impudence and Virulence in ≈øuch a Time as this, again≈øt ≈øo potent, ≈øo religious, ≈øo re≈øolute, ≈øo well-accompli≈øh't, well-di≈øciplin'd, and victorious an Army; the Ju≈øtice of who≈øe proceedings, as it triumphs beyond Apologie (being back't with all the Rea≈øon of an Honourable policy, and undeniable expedients for the good of the Kingdome;) ≈øo it mu≈øt indeare them to the pre≈øent, and ≈øhall innoble them to all future generations.

Therefore touching the fir≈øt of the≈øe Cob-web-contrivanes by way of Querie, wherein tho≈øe un≈øpotted Letters and Declarations from the Army (no le≈ø≈øe admirable for Stile than Equity) are mo≈øt maliciou≈øly traduced as of dangerous Con≈øequence; and the incomparable Generall, Officers, and Souldiers, taxed of Arbitrarine≈ø≈øe, and breach of the Hou≈øes privileges, becau≈øe tho≈øe Declarations and Charge again≈øt the Members went to the Pre≈ø≈øe without Leave from the Hou≈øe; I ≈øuppo≈øe the generall approbation of men, and the ≈øudden de≈øertion of tho≈øe Members (Argument enough of guilt) will clearely evince, that their Complaints were not cau≈øele≈ø≈øe, but of onely concernment and Con≈øequence to the Intere≈øt, Peace, and Happine≈ø≈øe
‚Ä¢ f the Engli≈øh Nation, again≈øt all foraigne Incroachments of tho≈øe, who≈øe practice is, under pretence of Reformation, by them≈øelves and ≈øome Apo≈øtate (with many deluded) Engli≈øhmen their Agents, to make what Mercats they plea≈øe of the Publique, to ≈øerve private ends. And further, it is time to con≈øider what
manner of men the≈øe are, and what Tyranny they would not execute (were their power an≈øwerable to tho≈øe bitter pa≈ø≈øions, which they give us a Ta≈øte of upon every lea≈øt occa≈øion) ≈øeeing they interpret ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary and harmele≈ø≈øe an Act in the Army, as a bare permi≈ø≈øion of their Papers to the Pre≈ø≈øe, into a ≈øen≈øe of Arbitrarine≈ø≈øe and breach of Privilege; whereas they have done nothing this way, but what is mo≈øt equitable in order to their owne vindication, and ≈øatisfaction of the whole Kingdome, who≈øe ignorance of the grounds of their ≈øo meritorious Ingagement, might have made them capable to entertaine any mon≈øtrous impre≈ø≈øions and repre≈øentations what≈øoever, again≈øt the Proceedings of the Army. And truely, it is high time al≈øo, that ≈øome Cour≈øe were taken for ≈øtating the Privileges of Parliament into certaine Limits, that men may no longer wander in this particular, as in a wilderne≈ø≈øe or Maze, nor run upon every Turne of humour and di≈øcontent, to ≈øecure them≈øelves and their De≈øignes, in the various, endle≈ø≈øe, and invi≈øible Labyrinth of Parliamentary privilege.

Touching the ≈øecond Querie, wherein the Proceedings of the Army are ≈øaid to be the ≈øame with Jack Cade and his rebellious popular Army, and ≈øo an Argument is founded upon this Suppo≈øition, on that Statute of 31. Hen. 6. cap. 1. concerning the Rebellion of Cade, to nullifie the Charge again≈øt the Members now Impeached, viz. that ALL INDITEMENTS (or Charges) IN TIME COMMING IN LIKE CASE, UNDER POWER OF TYRANNY, REBELLION, or STIRRING HAD, SHALL BE OF NO RECORD NOR EFFECT, BUT VOID IN LAW; and ≈øo not to be received now by the Parliament till the Army be disbanded. An Argument as rare, as the mad Impudence of tho≈øe many vile and inhumane A≈øper≈øions wherewith he hath be≈øpattered his Paper, is horrid and unpardonable! But fir≈øt, to wipe away that of Tyranny, it cannot be unknown to all men, that as this Army behave them≈øelves with ≈øo much Temper, that few where they come have Cau≈øe to complaine of wrong or dammage, ≈øo the Principall motive of their thus Ingaging is, to Cru≈øh that Serpent in the Shel, which (if hatched to maturitie) would have given an irrecoverable wound to Monarchy and Libertie; and as the
Kingly power mu≈øt have beene rendred as contemptible here, as the ≈øame de≈øigne hath made it beyond Tweed; ≈øo the freedome of the ≈øubject mu≈øt have dwindled into the ≈øame mi≈øery, leanne≈ø≈øe, and povertie, or wor≈øe than many of our poore Countrymen doe ≈øuffer, as ≈ølaves under the power of A≈øia.

And as for Rebellion, the ≈øecond gudgeon which this booki≈øh mad-man hath fi≈øh't out of the ≈øtatute, for his friends to ≈øwallow in opinion again≈øt the Army; It is a mo≈øt ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe thing to call that a Rebellion again≈øt Parliament, when men doe Act meerly for tho≈øe Ends, whereto they were fir≈øt Commi≈ø≈øionated by Parliament, again≈øt a vi≈øible Plot of particular men on foot, to amu≈øe, abu≈øe, and ≈øurprize the Parliament under-hand ≈øo farre, as to make them upon mi≈ø-informations, contribute toward the prejudice of the whole Kingdome and them≈øelves, in di≈ø-countenancing and di≈ø-contenting this Army; to whom (next under God) the Nation mu≈øt owe the re-inve≈øtiture of freedome, again≈øt the ≈øecret underminings of all ≈øuch darke-lanthorne Patriots. For, though their Adver≈øaries make an Advantage by ≈øcandalizing them as enemies to the Privileges of Parliament, (which is the maine de≈øigne of our Sotti≈øh Lawyer throughout his Queries) yet it cannot be ≈øo taken, ≈øince the Charge reflects onely upon a prevailing partie of private Intere≈øts, many of which have unduely crept into the Hou≈øe to ≈øerve by-ends, and over-awe the more Noble Partie; and ≈øo being in this de≈øperate condition, think to ≈øhelter them≈øelves under the notion of Parliamentary privilege, that they may with the more libertie and ≈øecuritie, contrive the ruine of tho≈øe greater ends, for who≈øe protection and pre≈øervation they were fir≈øt admitted or intended (viz. the Rights and Privileges of the People;) ≈øo that the Army in accu≈øing the Heads of the≈øe men, cannot be ≈øaid to infringe the Privileges of Parliament, but rather to pre≈øerve them, le≈øt through the infection of corrupt Members, they be tainted with Infamy, by being extended to countenance private wrongs or publique mi≈øchiefe. Nor is this onely a ≈øurmi≈øe to gaine a good opinion of the Army; for that needs not, ≈øeeing their Intentions are ≈øo apprehended by mo≈øt people of the Kingdome, not onely in point of the Hou≈øes privileges, but al≈øo in relation to the common freedome of the ≈øubject, with a Re≈øtauration
of the King in Parliament with ≈øuch Honour and freedome, as may gaine a la≈øting Repute to tho≈øe Acts that ≈øhall be provided for by the Royall A≈ø≈øent, in that behalfe: which (to the joy and happine≈ø≈øe of all true Engli≈øhmen, that have not lo≈øt them≈øelves in a Scotti≈øh-Mi≈øt) wil prove the ble≈ø≈øed con≈øequence of that unparallel'd piece of Vertue in the Army, which is ≈øo perniciou≈øly bla≈øted with a Story of Iack Cade, and a phrentick ≈ølander of Rebellion and Tyranny.

To the third Querie, wherein the Charge is excepted again≈øt, as too generall and ambiguous, again≈øt eleven eminent Members, mo≈øt of which have done gallant ≈øervice in the field, without de≈øcending to particulars of per≈øons, fact, time, place, &c. and ≈øo a mo≈øt illegall, injurious, arbitrary accu≈øation and proceeding, contrary to all Rules of Ju≈øtice and Equity: I ≈øhall extract ≈øeverall Pa≈ø≈øages out of the Armies owne Papers, in ju≈øtification of their Charge again≈øt all prejudice and calumny; as fir≈øt, the Conclu≈øion of the Charge it ≈øelfe (if the eager Gentleman had not overlook't it) might have ≈øatisfied him that they intended not to dwell upon Generals, though it were fir≈øt offered in ≈øuch termes, but de≈øcend to make good in particulars, each Head again≈øt ≈øome of the Per≈øons, and ≈øome one head or more again≈øt each of the Per≈øons; and ≈øhortly to give in the ≈øeverall particulars again≈øt each Per≈øon re≈øpectively, and make them good by proofes, when the Hou≈øe of Commons ≈øhould admit thereof; the Army de≈øiring to have and re≈øerve to them≈øelves, the liberty of exhibiting any farther Charge again≈øt all or any of the ≈øaid Per≈øons.

Heare al≈øo the words of the la≈øt Declaration from the Army, which ≈øay; Whereas many of the things whereto the Charge relates, are things ≈øpoken, moved, or done in the Hou≈øe, ≈øo as we have yet no cleare way opened, particularly to Charge or mention Them, or to produce proofes to Them, without ≈øome pretence again≈øt us of breach of Priviledge; and therefore (though we thinke no priviledge ought to protect evill men in doing wrong to particulars, or mi≈øchiefe to the publique, yet) we have been hitherto ≈øo tender of Parliament Privileges, as that we have only Remon≈øtrated the evill of ≈øuch things done; and ≈øuppo≈øing the Hou≈øe to have been (as we did and do beleeve, and if way were open without breach of Priviledge,
≈øhould not doubt to prove it was) ≈øome waies mi≈øinformed, deluded, ≈øurprized, or otherwi≈øe abu≈øed in tho≈øe things by evill Members, we have frequently in former Papers (before the Charge) put the Parliament upon it (who without colour of breach of Privilege might do it) to find out and di≈øcover who they were that had ≈øo abu≈øed Them, and to di≈ø-ingage the Honour of Parliament from ≈øuch evill practices and de≈øignes of ≈øuch Incendiaries.

So that after ≈øo manife≈øt Remon≈øtrating to accu≈øe and convince them by particulars, what doth our Lawyer, but play the Jack, by crying out inju≈øtice, injury, iniquity, and illegality of proceeding, upon ≈øurmi≈øed grounds of the Armies mannaging the Charge in generall, ambiguous, and uncertaine termes, which they have thus publiquely di≈øclaimed?

As to the other part of this Querie, wherein it is ≈øaid the King him≈øelfe hath given the lye to ≈øome of the Armies Declarations, touching his willingne≈ø≈øe to remove from Holdenby, and Cornet Joyce his ≈øeizing his Per≈øon was a trea≈øonable Action. I ≈øhall not ≈øtand to ju≈øtifie the Cornets Act as tolerable by the rigour of the Law (by which only this confu≈øed Lay-Go≈øpeller condemnes it;) but if we looke upon the impul≈øive Cau≈øe prevailing upon the Souldiery to attempt it, which was (as ≈øaies the la≈øt Declaration) the apprehen≈øion of private de≈øignes upon the King ere he came from Holdenby, to put his Maje≈øtie within the reach of tho≈øe mens power, who ≈øought for the advantage of his Per≈øon, thereby to imbroyle this Kingdome in a new and bloudy War, and ≈øtrengthen them≈øelves in their mi≈øchievous de≈øignes, the better to uphold their Faction, and intended domination; then we ≈øhall find that this ≈øeizing (or rather re≈øcue) of the Kings Per≈øon, was the very key of the worke, to locke up that Cabinet of ≈øecret Trea≈øons then and ≈øince di≈øcovered, which (like Pandora's Box) might el≈øe have repleni≈øhed the world with mi≈øchiefes greater than before, and to unlocke that doore of future peace, which they and their confidents had barred up again≈øt the Kingdomes happine≈ø≈øe: So that if Cornet Ioyce hath out-witted them, though in ≈øomewhat an irregular way again≈øt the Letter of the Law, yet I tru≈øt this Nation will beare him out again≈øt all rigorous Lawyers, becau≈øe of the happy con≈øequence
and effect it will produce both to Prince and People, by ≈øetting a period to one tumultuous War, and hindring the Progre≈ø≈øe of a ≈øecond, which mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have involved us in inevitable ruine. Nor do they yet give over the de≈øigne, but u≈øe all meanes to worke his Maje≈øty (who≈øe wi≈ødome I doubt not is proofe again≈øt all flatteries tending to his ruine) to ingage and declare for them, or at lea≈øt to declare Him≈øelfe a pri≈øoner, thereby to ≈øtir up His Party again≈øt the Army, who are the ≈øure Guardians of his Crowne and Per≈øon.

To the fourth Querie, which is ≈øtuffed with a Rabble of ≈ølander; as that it was but a pretence of the Army about fal≈øe informations, mi≈ø-repre≈øentations, and ≈øcandalous ≈øugge≈øtions, made again≈øt them to the Hou≈øe: For this I hope the Hou≈øe will puni≈øh him in calling their wi≈ødome ≈øo far in que≈øtion, as to make the world beleeve ≈øo grave a Senate ≈øhould upon a meere pretence of the Army retract one of their Declarations; and al≈øo right the Army from this ≈øcandall of pretence, by ≈øome reall example, to te≈øtifie a dete≈øtation of his abu≈øe both to Them≈øelves and the Army.

As al≈øo that the Army profe≈ø≈øe ungratefully and unchri≈øtianly touching the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Ireland in the ≈øecond, third, and fourth Articles of Charge. And what is it they profe≈ø≈øe there, but that charity begins at home? and ≈øeeing the Iri≈øh de≈øigne to be but a Plot to breake in pieces the Army, to make way for the advancement of their Faction here to the oppre≈ø≈øion and dedecoration of the Prince, Parliament, and People; and to leave them in ≈øuch a lame abject condition, that the Clergy-lay Conventiclers of the Faction might in the meane while in≈ølave them beyond recovery, they could not without offering violence to their principles, as Engli≈øhmen; to their Con≈øciences, as Reliligious men; and to common piety, as lovers of their Countrey; but ≈øtay and ≈øee the Flocke ≈øecured from being made a prey to tho≈øe Woolves here, who might in a ≈øhort time have proved as bad as tho≈øe that had devoured the prey already in Ireland; who≈øe la≈øt ruines mu≈øt be put upon their ≈øcore, as tho≈øe who by under-hand practices have hindred tho≈øe many ≈øupplies, which might have been ≈øpeeded away long ago, to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and redemption of that poore Kingdome.

To the fifth Querie, Whether the Army might not as well, by ≈øuch generall and uncertaine chargs, impeach the whole Hou≈øe its ≈øelfe as well as tho≈øe eleven Members? This is more mon≈øtrous than all the re≈øt, and calls aloud upon the Hou≈øe to vindicate their Honour from ≈øo foule a ≈øuppo≈øition of guilt, which he endeavours to throw upon them all, equally with the Members impeached and their party, and endeavours to in≈øinuate into mens minds, as if it were the ca≈øe of the whole Hou≈øe, which as it is contrarie to that reverence which the Army owes, and will expre≈ø≈øe to the Worthies of the Hou≈øe, ≈øo it requires the wi≈ødome of tho≈øe Worthies to correct the crafty ≈øawcine≈ø≈øe of our Lawyer in vindication of their own credit, and terrifie other malepert Boutefeux of the faction from the like audacitie.

As for his parallelling the Kings demand of the five Members heretofore and the Armies of eleven now, were it not time to leave off the mention of ought that may reflect upon him now, in a time when his honour and the Kingdomes peace are a repairing both together, I could manife≈øt a great di≈ø-proportion (in regard of circum≈øtances) betwixt that act of the Kings, and this of the Army, and prove the invalidity of the in≈øtance. And whereas he prints that ordinary ≈øcandall in the mouthes of all that are of the faction, that the remove of the impeached Members is endeavoured, onely that the Independent party might ≈øway and vote what they plea≈øe; what is it but to yeeld that tho≈øe men were the heads of the faction, and held an influence on a great part of the Hou≈øe to ≈øerve their owne de≈øigne? who the (Grandees being withdrawne) may chance now to prove hone≈øt; which our furious Lawyer needed not to have exclaimed again≈øt ≈øo fearfully, if he had thought they had been ingaged upon ≈øuch principles before, as would have rendred them la≈øting friends to the faction: But now, they being gone, it's like every Bowie may run with its owne Byas, I mean con≈øcience, and every tub ≈øtand upon its owne bottome. Then ≈øure that will appeare but an ill cau≈øe, who≈øe Fautors grow jealous of thriving by faire play above board.

To the ≈øixth Querie, Wherein he taxes the Army as quarrelling
at the Hou≈øes Votes, on purpo≈øe to keep from a di≈øbanding, to over-awe Parliament, City and Kingdome, and endeavouring to throw all old and new elected Members out of the Hou≈øe, that are not of their Party, with ≈øome exceptions al≈øo at the latter Elections in Cornwall, Wales, &c. for the prevention of which, and the conquering tho≈øe other Gugawes rambled up in this ≈øixth Querie, our Lawyer de≈øires to awaken all hone≈øt men in time. And ≈øurely, had not men need of an awakening, the Presbyters faction had never been adorned with ≈øo many Pro≈øelites in England; but now it is high time to open their eyes, that they may ≈øee who the men are, that have hoi≈øted up ≈øuch Votes by indirect means, on purpo≈øe to pick a quarrell with the Army, by putting them upon ≈øuch extraordinary waies for the ≈øafety of them≈øelves and the Kingdom, as in a time of le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øity and danger, they could not have adventured without a blemi≈øh of their Reputation: And it is ≈øo much the more trouble to them, to be reduced to this pa≈ø≈øe through the ≈øubtilty of their Adver≈øaries, that they cannot a≈ø≈øert the honour, freedome, and Priviledges of Parliament, but that they take occa≈øion to wre≈øt all their proceedings in Sequiorem, and repre≈øent them as Anti-Parliamentary, to the in-ob≈øerving and more ea≈øie under≈øtandings.

As concerning the Elections in Cornwall, &c. I had rather take the ≈øen≈øe of the Army, many of whom have been pre≈øent there, than the opinion of our Lawyer, who pronounces them all faire, with as much confidence as if Mahomets Pidgeon gave him Intelligence from all corners of the world.

In the ≈øeventh Querie he huddles over many Particulars of the ≈øame nature with tho≈øe in ≈øome of the former; and both the ≈øeventh and eighth containe nothing but matter of railing, ≈øcaudall, and mi≈ørepre≈øentation, pretending that the Army acts again≈øt the Parliament and their Priviledges, which I have ≈øufficiently refuted upon the former Queries; and ironically flouting them with the name of Saints, Saviours, Protectors, and the godly Party, telling them, they comply with the Malignants once in armes, complaining of the Breach of Articles, and craving reparation for their wrongs, &c. But he never con≈øiders, that equity is due to our wor≈øt enemies; and being loth
to give the Army the honour of their humane and equitable intentions, never tells upon what gronnd they are thus compa≈ø≈øionate to their quondam-Adver≈øaries; which certainly expre≈ø≈øes as much honour and ju≈øtice, together with hope of tranquillity to the Kingdom, as can po≈ø≈øibly be imagined, by a due con≈øideration of the right, quiet, and immunity of His Maje≈øty, his royall Family, & late Partakers; ≈øuppo≈øing a ≈øpirit of common love and ju≈øtice, diffu≈øing it ≈øelfe to the good and pre≈øervation of All, wil be the only way to make up the mo≈øt glorious Conque≈øt over their hearts (if God in mercy ≈øee it good) to make them and the whole People of the Land la≈øting Friends.

But the main Scandal in the eight Querie is a ≈øtory wherein he parallels the proceedings of the Army with the Anabapti≈øts at Mun≈øter, with the ≈øame ungracious impudence, as he does by the Rebellion of Iack Cade in the ≈øecond Querie, and ≈øo gives the City an Alarm to ≈øtand upon their Guard. It's well you'l be content with that po≈øture now, but certain it is, the De≈øigne, when it was fir≈øt conceived in darknes, and the privy Iunto of Confederates had travailed with it a whole night, was brought forth in the morning, a fair Cockney with the face of a new warr; which was nour≈øt up very carefully for a few daies, till the Citizens ≈øaw it would prove a very chargeable brat, and ≈øo it was immediatly ≈ømothered. I appland their wi≈øedom, that they were able to ≈øee them≈øelves made but a ≈øtalking-hor≈øe to ≈øerve other mens private ends; and I cannot but commend their re≈øolution to free them≈øelves from all ≈øuch like pur≈øemilking Complots for the future, which tend only to draw on the guilt of innocent blood, and draine the publick trea≈øure of the Kingdom and City, to ≈øupport the ambitious intere≈øts of particular men. And as for the Army, I doubt not but all men of this famons City unintere≈øted (or not wrought upon and amu≈øed by per≈øons Intere≈øted) are really ≈øatisfyed with their candid and ≈øincere Intentions towards this City, ≈øo often promi≈øed declared and remon≈øtrated: And if through the ≈øeditious provocations of ≈øuch furies as our Lawyer, they entertaine a cau≈øele≈ø≈øe jealou≈øie, and be urged thereby to act in prejudice of the Army, that pa≈ø≈øionate love which I beare to the renown and glory of this delight of the Nation, makes me tremble to
think into what fatall Con≈øequences ≈øuch cur≈øed Coun≈øellours would allure and in≈ønare them: And therefore they had be≈øt be well advi≈øed, that they behave them≈øelves with ≈øuch moderation, as to do nothing but in order to their owne defence, from the injuries of di≈øcontented enemies within, and without the lea≈øt ≈øhadow of provocation to their friends without, it re≈øting upon their wi≈øe carriage, either to burie the ≈øeeds of warre, ≈øedition and tumult, in an honourable Peace, or the happine≈ø≈øe and glory of Great Britaine, in a new Rupture.

To the ninth and la≈øt Querie, wherein he taxes the Armies demand of a ≈øpeedy An≈øwer to their Remon≈øtrance, to be the highe≈øt, arrogante≈øt, and unrea≈øonable≈øt that ever was propo≈øed, &c. I ≈øhall ≈øay no more but this, that nece≈ø≈øity admits of no delay in Affaires of this nature, ≈øeeing it were as much as to put them≈øelves to the hazzard of an After-game, when their enemies are vi≈øibly active upon the Counter-plot.

And I ≈øhall conclude only with one Anti-querie, in oppo≈øition to his nine Queries, viz: Whether if the Author of tho≈øe impudent, fal≈øe, and ≈øeditious Queries, have no eares to lo≈øe, hee de≈øerve not to bee cramp't in that right Thumb, which hath heretofore condemned ≈øo much Law and Divinity to confu≈øion; and now at la≈øt, mo≈øt impiou≈øly ≈øcandalized our be≈øt friends, as enemies of the Kingdom.
